name: Canyon Capers
description: Canyon Capers is a retro style platform game brought right up to date, with tons of levels, modes, collectables and secrets.
minimum_requirements: OS: Microsoft® Windows® XP / Vista / 7 / Windows 8 Processor: 1.4GHz or faster Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: Graphics Card made within the last 4 years (Pixel Shader 3.0, Vertex Shader 3.0) DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 250 MB available space Additional Notes: Microsoft Xbox 360 Controller or Direct Input compatible controller

reviews.review_text: 4/10    'Just not worth your time.'   CanyonCapers tries to be a classic 2D jump'n'run and succeeds by doing that... BUT this game just doesn't feel right in 2014 on PC & I give retro games usually good scores. Although it might be an okay mobile game for along the way, or for children up to the age of 6.   Pros:  + good controls  (slow, old school feeling)  + okay ost + okay gameplay + trading cards   Cons:  - no atmosphere - boring - doesn't make fun - collecting jewels&chests - simply not contemporary - not worth your precious gaming time   Just get   Commander KEEN   (for the retro lovers), or   Spelunky   (for the modern lovers) & definately pass on this one.

This game might have been a somewhat nice relaxing platformer to play after a long tiring day, if it weren't for the idiotic time limits. They are way too short, especially (but not only) in levels where you have to wait for elevators.  It adds unnecessary frustration to the otherwise mediocre game.

Dislcaimer: This game has nothing to do with canyons nor caping  Seriously, this game is a disgrace. You're an eleven year old boy that jumps on snakes that fart when they die and when you get hit, it sounds like a fourty year old is motor-boating his wife. You also need a VERY high end pc for the realistic graphics quality...  The only reason why you would get this game really is because you can get easy trading cards although I'd rather find another way. This game is only usable as a torture method, I'd rather suck D**K than playing this game.

I don't really like platformers that slide around & constantly having to correct mid-jump every jump, nor being time-limited & having to wait for sequences that are out of sync to come back into sync so I can move on, nor being spawned in-time to get hit every time I spawn. I got this for free from a bundle, and like all games, I gave it a fair shot. I got to level 8 before the game became unbearable to play. That's right, EIGHT levels in I had to put my controller down and decide if the hours of idling would be worth it for the cards.   It's a shallow platformer that's not very worthy to begin with before you add in floaty controls, unnecessary enemy knockback, jumps that require perfect placement or a large portion of the level must be replayed (only up to LEVEL 8, remember), backtracking through said tedious jumps because the coins you're required to collect are on 2 different paths, constantly changing objectives (one level you're collecting coins, the next they're just a bonus while you're defusing bombs, the next is just grab all chests), a bad HUD (health 'bar' is a shrinking heart icon with no indicator of actual HP #'s and the timer is just a color-changing line), and pointless mechanics (losing your health just respawns you, why have timed levels, and the enemies are just roadblocks that respawn if jumped on).   When it gets down to it, Canyon Capers is just jumping, collecting different items in linear levels, and occasionally more jumping on 'baddies' that get in your way. That's it. If that's what you enjoy, fire up some NES classics and play something from the good old days that's still good. Not this.

Canyon Capers tries to pull off a retro platformer styled gameplay, 'brought right up to date'. What you really get, however, is a classic example of why bringing up to date needs to be handled very carefully!  Pros:- - It's fun for about 30 minutes - You can get it cheap as a part of bundles, and even free if you scout hard - It has achievements and trading cards - I guess there IS a 'retro' feel somewhere there  Cons:- - Irritating pushbacks by random monsters (i.e. controls are not the friendliest) - Bad soundtrack and effects - Boring after the first 30 or so minutes - Wash-rinse-repeat gameplay  I got the game for free, and made 21 cents off selling its trading cards... Dunno why I'm complaining!

More and more I see why games with 'mixed' reviews get them. This game ruins platforming. You are on a specific time each level, and you must collect part/everthing in the level. All the levels look the same, and the items you collect don't actually do anything. If you get touched you go flying backward, which is always such a stupid inclusion in platformers. The guy jumps terribly and awkwardly. It sucks having every level ruined because you missed 1 tiny item, or how you didn't plan your route perfectly, meaning its trial and error. Another problem is every level is linear, meaning if you want to get to the upper right and you're in the lower right, you have to get to the middle, then go right, then left, then right, and youll be there, because thats the single way to go there, which leads to backtracking. I jsut sick of retrying levels because this isn't a real platformer with progressing levels, objectives, or story. Just collect-a-thon where you need to 'collect all gems in 45 seconds or restart level until you can'. Busch League. 4/10.

Canyon Capers is a quickly blended mixture of 90s graphics, giving you a little bit of the kiddy feel, and a few modern platformer features. This isn't a get to the exit game, it is an objective based game. I didn't enjoy it too much, but it does have its own good parts, like that 'ooh so close I wanna try once more' feel. And it has got trading cards too! (Probably the only reason I play it)   Verdict: If you want a quick game experience, that isn't too indepth, go for Canyon Capers. Not too recommended for Hardcore gamers.

Offensively mediocre.  Not horrible in any single aspect, but this game somehow manages to be less than the sum of its parts.   Some graphics scale awkwardly, making them blurry. The game feels like a mobile port. There are really annoying, unskippable animations. The game feels very unresponsive in the menus. The style isn't consistent at all.  But worst of all, it's just plain not fun. It feels like a chore.  I do like the little lens flare effect the gems give off and the flip-jump thing. If only that little attention to detail would've been carried over to the UI, level design and overall polish, Canyon Capers could've been a pretty okay game.

I don't know what it is about this game that I find so unpleasant.   Could it be the graphics that remind me of cheap kids birthday party accessories.   That when the character jumps he spins, albeit there are unlockable characters, I just couldn't be bothered.  Or could it be that the game is not about exploration just jumping around collecting gems in same same looking boxed environments.  I think its the fact that so much work has been put into this game, it seems really polished. It's polished like a tasteless aunties collection of porcelain girl and boy shelf figures. They'll never go on antiques roadshow, they're ugly and they're tacky, but your aunty with the blue hair and voice that grates on your ears love them.  I love Risk of Rain, a game, where you jump around limited environments, collecting stuff and unlocking characters. Sounds similar, it's just that, that game doesn't have a visual style I find nauseating.  I think I'll recommend this game, not because I like it, because we need different tastes, and we need that tacky aunty, with porcelain puppy dogs on her mirror shelves or whatever.  So if you like the visual style, what you'll get it a decent polished game.
